cmCourseInfo.description: Society and culture from various anthropological perspectives: socio-cultural, evolutionary, archaeological, and linguistic.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Anthropology

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

The two-hour weekly online lectures will be delivered at the scheduled time and posted online. Tutorials will be synchronous and students will enrol through Quercus. Office hours will be online.

courses.name: Making, Using, and Interpreting Stone Tools

cmCourseInfo.description: Stone tools are the earliest and longest-lasting record of human technology. This course explores interpreting stone tools from a multidisciplinary perspective. In making, using, and studying stone tools, students will learn how archaeologists form hypotheses and design experiments to understand humans and their technologies in the past. This course presents research that investigate changes in human ancestors’ cognition and livelihoods through the contributions of other disciplines in life and social sciences to the study of stone tools. The course introduces major stone tool discoveries and critically engages with current research through the development of new ideas for research projects. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Making, Using, and Interpreting Stone Tools

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students will be expected to watch asynchronous lecture videos prior to class meetings. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and/or camera to participate in the online-synchronous class discussion and other activities. Class discussions and other in-class activities will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. A class discussion board with also facilitate continued discussion among students asynchronously.

courses.name: Tragically Unhip: Great Thinkers of the Late 19th and Early 20th Centuries

cmCourseInfo.description: Inspired by Darwin’s Origin of Species (1859), the first anthropologists tried to extend his theory of evolution into culture by searching for the origins and essence of human existence. The course focuses on English and French thinkers who defined minimal sets of beliefs and practices that all cultures shared. It also takes account of the motivations and social milieux of early theorists who rarely, if ever, came in contact with the exotic “other” they studied; and it touches on the radical critique of their theories including Lévi-Strauss' structuralism and influential “afterologies” like deconstruction, post-structuralism, Lacanian psychoanalysis and Foucauldian philosophy. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Tragically Unhip: Great Thinkers of the Late 19th and Early 20th Centuries

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course.  Seminars will be held once week: Tuesdays 4pm to 6 pm EST.  Students are required to do the readings assigned for each week in the Course Syllabus before each Seminar and to participate in the synchronous discussion.  Open-ended follow-up discussion will continue asynchronously on Quercus.  Students will have the opportunity to ask the instructor questions and clarifications about course content once a week by appointment during the synchronous online office hour.  Students need the ability to use Power Point, Quercus, Blackboard Collaborate, and MS Teams.  Tests and Quizzes will be timed and online.

courses.name: Living on the Water in Toronto

cmCourseInfo.description: What do the Great Lakes mean to people living here? Especially Indigenous people? When and how do people care about the Great Lakes? Poems, stories, social science offer perspectives on the water from anthropology and arts. Field trips including paddling on a river, hiking; talks with local activists and artists. Restricted to first-year students. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Living on the Water in Toronto

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students may be able to access some recordings of on-line and in-person sessions.  However, this will depend upon consent of all involved to share a recording, including instructor, other students, and guest speakers. These materials, when available, can be viewed after the course meeting. It is recommended for all on-line students to have a mike and camera in order to participate in this discussion-oriented class. Because this course will have students participating both in-person and in on-line synchronous modes, it will also be helpful for students registered in the in-person section  to have a laptop with mike and camera, if you wish to interact (e.g. in discussion groups) with students who are on-line.

cmCourseInfo.description: How did art and technology develop in the course of human evolution? What led to the development of agriculture and settled village life? How did social inequality and urbanism emerge? This course takes a global perspective to explore the archaeological evidence that sheds light on these questions and other aspects of prehistory and early history. Students will engage with the challenges posed by new discoveries and also with recent developments in archaeological method and theory. The goal of the course is to involve students with the current state of archaeological research and some of the major issues archaeologists work to address.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Archaeology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

There will be two taped lectures, 45 minutes each, each week (asynchronous).  The tutorials will meet synchronously with the TA to discuss material and to provide guidance for applied exercises.  If public health guidelines allow, there may be some in person component. There will also be an optional (synchronous) drop in session with the instructor each week to cover any questions as they arise.  Assignments will include ten short 'Digging Into Writing' assignments per semester, a lab test, and a final written essay exam each term that will be timed.  Students will have access to their notes and reading material while writing the exam.  Reading will be the textbook World Prehistory and Archaeology: Pathways Through Time. 4th Edition, Routledge with occasional supplementary readings and films posted to Quercus.  TAs will be available for regular office hours or by appointment.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines where humans fit in the fabric of the natural world. It explores the history of ideas about humans in nature, humans as primates, the story of human evolution and modern human physical and genetic diversity.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Nature of Humans

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course includes asynchronous online lectures and synchronous online tutorials. Lectures will be given as 2-hour online videos/week asynchronously, and the instructor will be available for questions and discussions during the scheduled class time on BBCollaborate or a similar platform. Students will also have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours once a week to ask questions and clarifications about course content. Tutorials will take place online tutorials on Quercus, with TAs on BBCollaborate (or a similar platform) guiding students through the activities. Tutorial slots across the whole day will allow students in all time zones to participate. Students need the ability to read PDFs and use Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). Quizzes and tests will be timed and online.

courses.name: Social Cultural Anthropology and Global Issues

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: January 11, 2021: Section cancelled.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: January 11, 2021: Section cancelled.

cmCourseInfo.description: A course focused on recent anthropological scholarship that seeks to understand and explain the transformation of contemporary societies and cultures. Topics may include some of the following: new patterns of global inequality, war and neo-colonialism, health and globalization, social justice and indigeneity, religious fundamentalism, gender inequalities, biotechnologies and society etc.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Cultural Anthropology and Global Issues

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be livestreamed and recorded weekly either through Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) or zoom.  Tutorials will be synchronous. Students will participate in weekly discussions completed on Quercus. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours to ask questions and clarifications about course content. Students need the ability to read PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). Tests will be timed and online.

courses.name: Medical Anthropology: Sociocultural Perspectives on Illness, Medicine and Care

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to medical anthropology with a focus on questions, methods, and insights from sociocultural anthropology. Explores the relationships among culture, society, and medicine with special attention to power, inequality, and globalization. Examples from many parts of the world, addressing biomedicine as well as other healing systems.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medical Anthropology: Sociocultural Perspectives on Illness, Medicine and Care

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be given as 2-hour online videos/week asynchronously and discussion will be completed on Quercus. Tutorials will be held online with synchronous meetings. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours 3 times per week to ask questions and clarifications about course content. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). Tests will be timed and online.

courses.name: Core Concepts in Social and Cultural Anthropology

cmCourseInfo.description: Society, culture, kinship, exchange, community, identity, politics, belief: these and other core concepts are explored in this course, which lays the foundation for advanced courses in social and cultural anthropology.
cmCourseInfo.title: Core Concepts in Social and Cultural Anthropology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Course lectures will be provided asynchronously via audio recordings in Powerpoint. Students must be able to download the Powerpoint presentations and watch videos online. Tutorials will be online synchronous at their scheduled times. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Medical Anthropology: an Evolutionary Perspective on Human Health

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to applied evolutionary medical anthropology. It explores evidence for the evolution of human vulnerability to disease across the life cycle (conception to death) and implications for health of contemporary populations in behavioral ecological, cross-cultural, health and healing systems, historical trauma, inter-sectionality, and climate change, lenses.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medical Anthropology: an Evolutionary Perspective on Human Health

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will be available for students to view asynchronously. They will be posted each week on Monday night. Tutorials will be available only as online synchronous, and in person at their scheduled times (see Calendar). Students are expected to view recorded lectures prior to meeting virtually with their Teaching Assistant for online synchronous tutorials. For tutorials, it would be helpful for students to have access to a microphone and/or camera. Access to a microphone and/or camera would also be helpful if students want to meet with the instructor virtually during their synchronous office hours on Friday afternoons, 3-4 PM EST.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces linguistic analysis with a view towards its application to the study of the relation between culture and social structure. The interplay of pronunciation, grammar, semantics, and discourse with rituals, ideologies, and constructions of social meaning and worldview are discussed in tandem with the traditional branches of linguistic analysisphonology, morphology, grammar, syntax, and semantics. The objective of the course is to provide a broad framework for understanding the role of language in society.
cmCourseInfo.title: Language & Society

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be recorded and made available online for asynchronous viewing.  Office hours will take place online at regularly scheduled times and by appointment.  The midterm test and final exam will be taken online during a designated, time-limited window.

cmCourseInfo.description: An archaeological survey of the human prehistory of northwestern North America from the late Pleistocene to the time of early European contact. Geographical coverage will include the Northwest Coast, California, and the Intermontane Plateau.
cmCourseInfo.title: Archaeology of the Pacific Northwest
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT200Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Classes will be delivered online synchronously. Lectures will also be recorded and available asynchronously which registered students can access on their own time. Students would need Bb Collaborate.

courses.name: The Preindustrial City and Urban Social Theory

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers a comparative examination of the rise and organization of ancient cities through a detailed investigation of urban social theory. We will explore competing anthropological interpretations of urban process while probing the political, ideological, and economic structures of the worlds earliest cities. Students will have the opportunity to consider a broad range of subjects, including mechanisms of city genesis; urban-rural relations; the intersections of city and state; and historical variation in urban landscapes, ideologies, and political economies.
cmCourseInfo.title: The Preindustrial City and Urban Social Theory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT200Y1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous/asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as 2-hour online videos each week synchronously for students who wish to participate in live discussion at the end of lecture.  However, the lecture will also be recorded for students unable to virtually attend the class during the designated time period. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours once per week to ask questions and clarifications about course content.  Email-based office hours for students in different time zones is also an option.  Students need the ability to read PDFs of PowerPoint lecture slides. Take-home exams will be uploaded to Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will present various perspectives on the nature and dynamics of youth culture. It will discuss the research accumulated over the past quarter century on youth lifestyles, from fashion and music to the formation and spread of slang. It will also look at the various critical and controversial aspects of adolescence in contemporary culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Anthropology of Youth Culture
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT204H1 or ANT207H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Audio-recordings of lectures will also be available for students to access asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and a camera in order to participate in the course activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: The role of language and symbolism in the representation and manipulation of ideology and power structure. Case materials drawn from the study of verbal arts, gender, law, advertising, and politics with a focus on North America.
cmCourseInfo.title: Language & Power Structure
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT204H1 or ANT207H1 or ANT253H1 or VIC223Y1 or one of 200+ series H1 course in SOC or POL or LIN or Women's Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be delivered synchronously, and also recorded for asynchronous viewing. In tutorial meetings, students need to engage in discussion with one another. Tutorials will be online synchronously. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). Tests will be timed and online.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 22, 2020: Delivery Method cancelled

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 22, 2020: Delivery Method cancelled

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of living primates, this lab-oriented course describes and compares the diverse behavioural and anatomical adaptations that are characteristic to this order of mammals. The understanding of the biological diversity and evolutionary history of primates is important for further understanding of human adaptation and evolution.
cmCourseInfo.title: Living Primate Adaptations
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT203Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures and practicals will be given online, synchronously and discussion will be completed on Quercus. Practicals will be given online, synchronously. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours each week to ask questions and clarifications about course content. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). Tests will be timed and online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Exploration of the development and maintenance of the human skeleton and dentition, with emphasis on application to archaeological, forensic and biomedical sciences.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human Skeletal Biology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT203Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be both synchronous and asynchronous (live-streams that will be recorded and made available asynchronously). Practicals will be synchronous. This is an online course. Lectures will be given as 2-hour synchronous live-streamed webinars that will also be made available asynchronously for all students. The practical component will be hosted online with digital content accessible via Quercus. There will be two 2-hour online practical session time slots. During the online practical sessions, teaching assistants and the instructor will be available for students to ask questions and receive assistance with course content. Students will need the ability to access PDFs, PowerPoint slides, and videos on Quercus, as well as web-based streaming platforms such as Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) and Microsoft Teams. All assessments will be timed and delivered online.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course takes the student on a survey of human evolution from our ape ancestors to modern humans. Students will learn to identify skulls, teeth and limb bones, explore hundreds of casts, and learn how researchers understand human origins and trends in the development of human anatomy and behavior.
cmCourseInfo.title: Human Evolution
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT203Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course consisting of lectures and labs. 

Lectures will be given each week as 2-hour online PowerPoint presentations with accompanying audio. 

Labs will consist of video demonstrations of lab materials (fossils and living primates) that can be viewed as desired. 

Students can pause the lectures at indicated points to view an explanatory video demonstration and view them again anytime within each of the separate sections of the course. 

Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours 3 times per week to ask questions and clarifications about course content. Students need the ability to read PDFs and PowerPoint slides. Tests will be online take-home exams based on both the lecture and lab material. Completed tests will be submitted using Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course will explore the foundational and leading concepts in evolutionary anthropology. Historically important readings and current concepts will be presented and discussed in the context of research, especially in areas of human population biology, ecology and the evolution of Homo sapiens. Topics will include behavioral ecology and life history theory, as well as a critique of the adaptationist program.
cmCourseInfo.title: Evolutionary Anthropology Theory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT203Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online course. Lectures will be given as 1 hour online videos/week asynchronously with students expected to watch them in preparation for the class. The class will meet for questions and discussions during the scheduled class time on BBCollaborate. Discussions will be on BBCollaborate and on the Quercus discussion boards. Office hours will be online, by appointment. The synchronous class meetings will be recorded and available on Quercus. Students need to be able to read PDFs and use Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). Quizzes will be timed and online, essay submissions also online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Molecular anthropology is an interdisciplinary field combining biology, genetics, evolution and anthropology. In this class, we will explore the use of DNA for the study of past migrations and admixture patterns, the evolution of pathogens, plant and animal domestication and especially the relationships between recent and archaic humans.
cmCourseInfo.title: Molecular Anthropology and Human Evolution
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT203Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online course. Lectures will be given as 2-hour online videos/week asynchronously, and the instructor will be available for questions and discussions during the scheduled class time on BBCollaborate or a similar platform. Discussions will be in the classroom and on the Quercus discussion boards. Tutorials will be online synchronous. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours once a week to ask questions and clarifications about course content. Students need to be able to read PDFs and use Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). Quizzes will be timed and online, essay submissions also online.

cmCourseInfo.description: Social anthropological perspectives on variations in gender roles and systems. Examines, through comparison of ethnography, the relationship of gender to social organization, economic and political processes, belief systems and social change.
cmCourseInfo.title: Social Anthropology of Gender
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT207H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This will class will be delivered synchronously. Recordings of some portions of lecture will also be available for students to view asynchronously. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines medical anthropologys contributions to, and critiques of, global health policies and programs. Topics covered include: colonialism and health, the political ecology of disease, indigenous constructions of illness and healing, medical pluralism, the politics of primary health care, population policies, reproductive health, and AIDS.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Health: Anthropological Perspectives
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT207H1 or permission of the instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course, but lectures will be recorded so that students have the option of viewing them asynchronously. Lectures will be given at the designated time, but will also be available as 2-hour online videos/week. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours 3 times per week to ask questions and clarifications about course content. Students need the ability to view PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). Tests will be timed and online.

courses.name: Medical Anthropology: Health, Power and Politics

cmCourseInfo.description: This course deepens students’ understandings of health and illness as social, cultural, political and historical phenomena. Drawing on theories and approaches from social-cultural anthropology, students will develop skills in critical analysis of experiences and meanings of healing and illness in particular contexts, with a focus on anthropological critique of dominant health policies, discourses, technologies and practices.
cmCourseInfo.title: Medical Anthropology: Health, Power and Politics
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT204H1 or ANT207H1 or permission of the instructor. (Note: ANT208H1 is not accepted preparation for this course.)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous lecture with asynchronous option. Live lectures and small group discussion will be scheduled weekly in 2-hour slots; audio recordings of lectures will be available. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours with the course instructor or TA, via video conferencing or telephone, at least 3 times per week to ask questions and seek clarification about course content. Students need the ability to read PDFs, watch online videos, and use Quercus and Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra).

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces anthropological definitions of religion; debates on rituals and rites of passage; rationality, religion and modernity; belief and body; religion and the media. It also engages with studies in the anthropology of popular and transnational religion, and the politics of religious movements.
cmCourseInfo.title: Anthropology of Religion
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT207H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course.  Lectures will be posted once a week Thursdays 4:10 pm to 6:00 pm EST on Blackboard Collaborate Ultra.  Students are required to do the readings assigned for each week in the Course Syllabus before each set of asynchronous lectures and, ideally, to reread them afterwards.  Open-ended follow-up discussion will take place on Quercus.  Students will have the opportunity to ask the instructor questions and clarifications about course content once a week by appointment during one hour or more of synchronous online office hours.  Students need the ability to use Quercus, Blackboard Collaborate Ultra, and MS Teams.  Tests and Quizzes will be timed and online. Written work to be submitted as .docx or pdf file.  Late work may be penalized.

courses.name: Anthropology of Activism and Social Justice

cmCourseInfo.description: Explores how anthropologists have traditionally studied social movements and how new social movements have challenged anthropologists to rethink some of their ethnographic methods and approaches. Some specific movements covered include those related to indigenous rights, environmentalism, refugees, gay and lesbian issues, biotechnology, new religions, and globalization.
cmCourseInfo.title: Anthropology of Activism and Social Justice
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT207H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. 

Lectures and discussions will be scheduled in 2-hour online medium (Zoom or Team). 

Students will have the opportunity for 1-hour synchronous online office hour after the class to ask questions and clarifications about course content. 

Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). 

There will be no test and all assignments will be submitted through online.

cmCourseInfo.description: An in-depth critical review of foundational ideas in the development of the practice of Anthropology. Topics may include questioning fieldwork, origins and legacies of functionalism, cultural materialism, politics of culture, power and political economy, globalization and post modernism, gender and post-structuralism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Introduction to Social Anthropological Theory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT207H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lecture will also be available to students to view asynchronously. Group discussions and exercises will be held online synchronously at the appointed class time.

courses.name: Rethinking Development, or the Improvement of the World

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: August 26, 2020: Course added

cmCourseInfo.description: Development, or deliberate intervention to improve the lives of people deemed to be lacking, or left behind, has shaped the modern world for at least a century. Drawing on historical and ethnographic studies, this course examines the trajectory of development as a concept and practice, and traces its effects.
cmCourseInfo.title: Rethinking Development, or the Improvement of the World
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT207H1 or permission of the instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students are expected to participate in zoom-based on-line synchronous small-group discussions which will occur at intervals throughout the 3-hour on-line lecture period.

cmCourseInfo.description: The relationship between humans and other animals is one of the most hotly debated topics of our times. Through key classic and contemporary writings, this course introduces students to the interdisciplinary field of animal studies, and explores how anthropologists and other theorists have critically engaged in debates about animal and human distinctions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Anthropology of Animals
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT204H1 or ANT207H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course. Weekly lectures will be posted to Quercus as 2-hour online modules. Students will be requested to post weekly assignments to Quercus and participate in weekly online Quercus discussion groups. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours 2 times per week to ask questions and clarifications about course content.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces dialogue between anthropological literature and other disciplinary studies in regards to the economy and culture of gift and money transaction as a key aspect of human society. Studying the history of gift and money economy from agricultural societies and diverse developments of finance market culture in recent era through various perspectives (e.g., ethnographic, sociological, politico-economic, and historical views), this course aims to train students developing a critical understanding of capitalism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Gift, Money, and Finance
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT204H1 or ANT207H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recording of lecture will be available upon request pending instructor's approval. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces students to the skills they need to conduct ethnographic research, in particular, participant observation, in-depth interview, as well as writing fieldnotes and research proposals. The emphasis is on interactive, workshop-style small group learning.
cmCourseInfo.title: Craft of Social/Cultural Anthropology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT207H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Class discussions will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

courses.name: Special Topics in Society, Culture and Language

cmCourseInfo.description: This lecture-format course focuses on a relatively broad topic in socio-cultural and/or linguistic anthropology. Topics change from year to year. For the 2015-16 academic year, the title of this course is "Nature, Culture, Human".
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Society, Culture and Language
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT207H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures will be given as 1-hour weekly pre-recorded videos available for viewing asynchronously, and discussion of the lecture will be completed for 1-hour on Quercus on the second hour of the time slot of the course. Please note that online pre-recorded lectures will only be available on the day of lectures from a time after the weekly deadline for students to send in comments on Quercus on the reading assignments for the week. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online 2-office hours per week to ask questions and clarifications about course content. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) or a similar platform. Tests will be online.

cmCourseInfo.description: This is a course on material religion and mediation, kingdom and kinship, gender symbolisms and devotions, ecologies of selves and the histories of senses that infuse Catholicism. It challenges us to think about the importance of Catholicism as a global phenomenon expressed through socio-political and cultural practices of the everyday life.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Catholicism: Anthropological Approaches
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT204H1 or ANT207H1 or SMC103Y1 or RLG212H1 or RLG203H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Lectures will be given as 1-hour weekly pre-recorded videos available for viewing asynchronously, and discussion of the lecture will be completed for 1-hour on Quercus on the second hour of the time slot of the course. Please note that online pre-recorded lectures will only be available on the day of lectures from a time after the weekly deadline for students to send in comments on Quercus on the reading assignments for the week. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online 2-office hours per week to ask questions and clarifications about course content. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) or a similar platform. Tests will be online.

courses.name: Anthropologists and Indigenous Peoples in North America

cmCourseInfo.description: Indigenous scholars (including anthropologists), intellectuals and activists have publicly challenged the ethical and political implications of anthropological research in, on and with Indigenous nations and communities. This course takes such critiques as jumping-off points from which to explore historical and contemporary relations between anthropologists and Indigenous peoples in North America.
cmCourseInfo.title: Anthropologists and Indigenous Peoples in North America
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT200Y1 or ANT203Y1 or ANT204H1 or ANT207H1 or ANT208H1 or ANT253H1
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation:
ABS201Y1

Distribution Requirement: Social Science

Breadth Requirement: Society and its Institutions (3)

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Recordings of lectures will be available for students to view asynchronously in preparation for participation in online-synchronous class meetings. For participation in online-synchronous class meetings, it is recommended that students have a computer with microphone and camera. Recordings of the online-synchronous class meetings (excluding breakout groups) will be made available for asynchronous viewing by those unable to participate.

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the diversity of recent hunter-gatherer societies, as a source of analogues for understanding the archaeological record of past foraging peoples.
cmCourseInfo.title: Hunter-Gatherers Past & Present
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ARH305H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

During each week of this course, students are expected to watch pre-recorded asynchronous lecture videos and attend an online synchronous discussion session. The asynchronous lecture videos will be posted weekly and will be accessible throughout the duration of the course. Students should watch the lecture videos prior to the synchronous discussion session. The discussion sessions will be both audio- and text-based, requiring students to have a device (e.g. computer, tablet, phone) with a microphone. A webcam is not required. The synchronous discussion sections will not be recorded or posted online after their scheduled time.

cmCourseInfo.description: Seminar in the critical examination of major schools of archaeological thought.
cmCourseInfo.title: Advanced Archaeological Theory
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ARH305H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students will be able to access recordings of each week’s 1-hour of lecture before the scheduled lecture time (Mondays 2-3pm); the first hour of the meeting time is devoted to the recorded lecture (which can also be viewed asynchronously); the second hour is devoted to group discussion over zoom (synchronous, 3-4pm each Monday). It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 20, 2020: Course changed to Online - Synchronous

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduces the problems, methods and some of the material culture of colonial and industrial archaeology with emphasis on Canada and colonial America. Covers the use of documentary evidence, maps, architecture, and a variety of artifact classes.
cmCourseInfo.title: Historical Archaeology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT200Y1 or HIS374H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is planned as an online course with assignments that students can carry out online or on their own. Lectures will be given as 1-hour or 2-hour online videos each week, asynchronously, followed by near-weekly, synchronous discussion sessions. Two of the three assignments in this course (archival research on a property and background research on an artifact) will involve online research that students can carry out at home with minimal equipment and supplies. The other assignment, should conditions allow, will involve students carrying out their own independent research in an historic cemetery. Students will carry out this “fieldwork” either alone or in groups of only two (with social distancing). If the fieldwork component is not possible, this will be changed to a computer-based analysis of a similar dataset. Students will have opportunities for synchronous online office hours before the deadline for submitting each research report to ask questions and obtain clarifications about instructions. Half-hour sessions for discussion and questions about the lectures or labs will use the chat functions on Quercus. Students will need to be able to read PDFs, watch YouTube videos and PowerPoint slides, and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). For the archival research, they may want to obtain trial memberships in Ancestry.ca (make sure to cancel within one week). Tests will be timed and online.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: July 8, 2020

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers a comparative survey of archaeological approaches to ritual practice as it relates to identity politics, personhood, and the negotiation of power relations in past societies. An important goal of the seminar is to introduce students to social theories on the inherent materiality of ritual performance, whether orchestrated in everyday practice or in elaborate religious and political spectacles.
cmCourseInfo.title: Archaeology of Ritual and Identity
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ARH305H1 and one of ANT100Y1/ANT200Y1/ANT356H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous/asynchronous course. Lectures will be given as 2-hour online videos each week synchronously for students who wish to participate in live discussion at the end of lecture.  However, the lecture will also be recorded for students unable to virtually attend the class during the designated time period. Students will have the opportunity for synchronous online office hours once per week to ask questions and clarifications about course content.  Email-based office hours for students in different time zones is also an option.  Students need the ability to read PDFs of PowerPoint lecture slides. Take-home exams will be uploaded to Quercus.

cmCourseInfo.description: How ideas about language fit into the overall views of humankind as expressed by selected anthropologists, linguists, sociologists, and philosophers.
cmCourseInfo.title: Language in Anthropological Thought
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT204H1 or ANT207H1 or ANT253H1 and 0.5 300+ level course from Group C

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be taught online synchronously. I may also give a short lecture to provide background information on the readings, to discuss the main issues, and to explain some technical concepts for the following session. Students need the ability to read and edit PDFs or PowerPoint slides and use Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra). 2 quizzes will be timed and online.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: October 9, 2020: Course added.

cmCourseInfo.description: The history and present of western concepts and images about the ‘Other’, in anthropological and other scholarship and in popular culture.
cmCourseInfo.title: Western Views of the Non-West
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 0.5 300 level FCE from Anthropology Group C (Society, Culture, Language), or NMC or Jewish Studies or Diaspora and Transnational Studies or History

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Students must have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. 

Attendance in the live, seminar-style class sessions is required. Exemptions may be granted in special circumstances at the instructor’s discretion. Students who must miss a class for a good reason should contact the instructor (in advance if at all possible), for a recording to be viewed asynchronously. 

Prior to class, students are expected to peruse preparatory material, which may include texts, podcasts, and video, as instructed on the syllabus (available on Quercus).

courses.name: Health, Diet & Disease in the Past

cmCourseInfo.description: Advanced exploration of the life histories of past populations, through the application of palaeodietary analyses, palaeopathology and other appropriate research methods.
cmCourseInfo.title: Health, Diet & Disease in the Past
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT334H1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online course.  Lectures will be both synchronous and asynchronous. Lectures will be given in one 2-hour synchronous live-stream that will also be made available asynchronously (recorded) for all students. Practical sessions will be synchronous and will consist of one 2-hour online practical session each week.  Students will need the ability to access PDFs, PowerPoint slides, and videos on Quercus, as well as web-based streaming platforms such as Blackboard Collaborate (Ultra) and/or Zoom. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

cmCourseInfo.description: A detailed review of the classic and recently emerging literature on the anthropology of children, childhood, and childcare. Focus is on theories for evolution of human parenting adaptations, challenges in research methodology and implications for contemporary research, practice and policy in the area of care and nutrition of infants and children.
cmCourseInfo.title: Anthropology of Childhood and Childcare
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT203Y1

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous course delivered through BB collaborate or Zoom. There will be no class recordings. There are no tutorials or practicals for this course. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: Biological Interactions Between Humans and Non-Human Animals

cmCourseInfo.description: Taught by an advanced PhD student or postdoctoral fellow, and based on his or her doctoral research and area of expertise, this course presents a unique opportunity to explore intensively a particular Evolutionary Anthropology topic in-depth. Topics vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Emerging Scholarship (Evolutionary Anthropology)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT203Y1 and 0.5 FCE 300+ Group B (Evolutionary) course

breadthTypes.description: BR=4 Living Things and Their Environment

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Short asynchronous lectures (~30 minutes) will be provided to students at least 48 hours before class meetings and will be available until the end of the course. Discussion will take two forms: written discussion posts and online-synchronous discussions during class time. Students are encouraged to use both audio and video for these online-synchronous discussions, but neither will be enforced.

cmCourseInfo.description: Beginning with anthropologys early work on kinship, and ending with recent analyses of sex work and the globalization of ideologies of romantic love and companionate marriage, this course will investigate how emotional and sexual relationships are produced, used, conceptualized, and experienced both within particular societies and transnationally.
cmCourseInfo.title: Love, Sex, and Marriage
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT207H1 and ANT343H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This course will be taught online synchronously. Prior to each session, I may also post short asynchronous lectures in order to outline the main themes, concepts, and arguments in the readings. There are no tutorials or practicals for this course. Office hours are available during weekly time periods and by appointment via Skype, Zoom, or Bb Collaborate. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and a camera in order to participate in online discussions. Students should be able to use Quercus, BlackBoard Collaborate Ultra, PowerPoint, and Zoom.

cmCourseInfo.description: As of 2007, for the first time in human history, more than half the world’s peoples lived in cities. It is estimated that by 2030 over 60% will be urban-dwellers. This demographic shift suggests that for many (if not most) people, their primary encounter with “nature” will be urban based. This course explores the idea of “urban-nature” by 1) focusing on the ways in which various theorists have challenged traditional ways of viewing both “the city” and “nature” and 2) encouraging students to develop their own critical perspectives through ethnographic engagements with the city of Toronto.
cmCourseInfo.title: Multispecies Cities
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT204H1 or ANT207H1 and a 300-level course or above in Society, Culture and Language

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course. Weekly lectures will be posted to Quercus as 2-hour online modules. Students will be requested to post weekly assignments to Quercus and participate in weekly online Quercus discussion groups. Students will also be asked to participate in a small online project, consisting of 3-4 persons. Students will be able to schedule one-on-one appointments with the instructor to ask questions and clarifications about course content.

courses.name: Ethnographic Approaches to the Middle East and North Africa

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the literature and concerns of anthropologists conducting ethnographic research in the greater Middle East and North Africa (MENA). It is designed for students with a background in social and cultural anthropology who wish to become familiar with the social and religious complexity of the MENA region, and the anthropological questions it has compelled. Islam has long been the area's principal social and historical force and thus provides the backdrop for much, but not all, of the ethnography considered in the course. Moreover, Muslim majority MENA countries exhibit considerable social and sectarian diversity. Readings and lectures attend to differences as well as resemblances, while considering issues such as gender roles, kinship, marriage, local level practices, medicine, secularism, 'public Islam,' nationalism, and the persistent problem of orientalism.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ethnographic Approaches to the Middle East and North Africa
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT207H1
cmCourseInfo.exclusionsText: ANTC89H3; ANT484H1 (Topics: Ethnography of the Middle East and North Africa) taken in Winter 2014; ANT384H1 (Topics: Peoples of the Middle East and North Africa) taken in Winter 2017, Winter 2018.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. Students will need access to a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities. Those students who wish to register for the course but are unable to attend synchronously are asked to email the instructor in advance of registration.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces perspectives which extend anthropological inquiry beyond the solely human realm. Building on an acknowledgement of the fundamental interconnectedness of humans and other life forms, it explores the agencies of other-than-humans, including nonhuman animals, land and seascapes, plants, bacteria, “contaminants,” and others. The course involves field-site visits and fieldwork projects in Toronto (GTA region) and engages with ethnographic methodologies best suited to investigations of inter-species, inter-life form relationships.
cmCourseInfo.title: Multispecies Ethnography
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT376H1 or three 300-level anthropology courses in any subfield or permission of instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, asynchronous course. Weekly classes will be posted to Quercus as online Self-Directed-Learning (SDL) modules. Students will be requested to post weekly assignments to Quercus and participate in weekly online Quercus discussion groups. Students will also be asked to participate in a small online project, consisting of 3-4 persons. Students will be able to schedule one-on-one appointments with the instructor to ask questions and clarifications about course content.

cmCourseInfo.description: This fourth-year seminar examines how female gender shapes health and illness. Using case studies of sexual health, fertility and its management, substance use/abuse, mental health, and occupational/labor health risks, the course investigates the material, political, and socio-cultural factors that can put women at risk for a range of illness conditions.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Perspectives on Womens Health
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT343H1 or ANT348H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online synchronous seminar with an emphasis on discussion. Sessions will not be recorded and will not be available for later viewing. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and a camera in order to participate in online discussion. Students should be able to use Quercus, BlackBoard Collaborate Ultra, PowerPoint, and Zoom.

courses.name: Japan in Global Context: Anthropological Perspectives (formerly ANT354Y1 and ANT354H1)

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines how what we know as Japan and its culture has been constructed through global interactions. Topics include gender and sexuality, race and ethnicity, social and family life, work and leisure, and Japanese identity amid changing global power relations.
cmCourseInfo.title: Japan in Global Context: Anthropological Perspectives (formerly ANT354Y1 and ANT354H1)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT204H1 or ANT207H1

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Class discussions will be available only as online synchronous at their scheduled times. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in online activities.

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: Aug 18, 2020: Course cancelled

cmCourseInfo.description: Students carry out original ethnographic research projects on some aspect of life in the University of Toronto: its students, staff and faculty; its hierarchies and habits; and the everyday practices in classrooms, labs, dining halls, offices, clubs, and residence corridors. Class time is used for collective brainstorming, feedback and analysis.
cmCourseInfo.title: Ethnographic Practicum: The University
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT380H1 or permission of the instructor

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This is an online, synchronous course. There will be no lectures. 

The class follows a seminar and workshop format in which participants present material for discussion in plenary and small group sections.

 Students should be prepared to do independent research in formats such as on-line research, zoom-based semi-structured interviews, and safe outside observation. 

Quercus is used for accessing course materials, posting blogs and assignments, and grade-keeping.

courses.name: Special Topics in Social Cultural Anthropology

cmCourseInfo.description: Unique opportunity to explore a particular Social Cultural Anthropology topic in-depth. Topics vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Special Topics in Social Cultural Anthropology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT207H1 and 1 FCE 300 level Group C (Society, Culture and Language) course

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

This will be an online-synchronous class. It is recommended that students have a computer with a microphone and camera in order to participate in the seminar discussion.

courses.name: Topics in Emerging Scholarship (Society, Culture and Language)

sections.name: LEC0101
sections.subTitle: The Anthropology of Textiles and Clothing

cmCourseInfo.description: Taught by an advanced PhD student or postdoctoral fellow, and based on his or her doctoral research and area of expertise, this course presents a unique opportunity to explore intensively a particular Socio-cultural or Linguistic Anthropology topic in-depth. Topics vary from year to year.
cmCourseInfo.title: Topics in Emerging Scholarship (Society, Culture and Language)
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: ANT207H1 and 1 FCE 300+ Group C (Society, Culture and Language) course

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Delivery Instructions

Lectures will be in the format of live class discussions via Zoom or Bb Collaborate. Office hours are available by appointment via Skype, Zoom, or Bb Collaborate. We will also offer live community drop-in sessions (optional) for students to practice the experiential learning components as a group, discuss or clarify course concepts, and be in community with one another. Students will need to be able to watch videos and listen to recordings, and will also need access to a microphone or headset. Video capability is strongly encouraged, but if students are unable to access a webcam alternatives can be discussed. This is a dynamic course with a focus on comprehension through experience. Although the course is completely online, most weeks you will participate in learning and practicing different textile and clothing production techniques such as weaving and beading. You will either pick-up on campus or we will mail you a package of all the supplies you will need to complete a small sample of the techniques.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course is an opportunity to apply acquired knowledge in anthropology or archeology in a work placement environment. Opportunities may include local community organizations, international development organizations, museum or heritage projects, or media production projects. Only internships that require knowledge and skills in anthropology and/or archeology will be considered. Student must fulfill responsibilities of the internship as well as complete a final research paper. If qualified, the student’s internship supervisor will mark the final paper for the course; if not, an appropriate academic supervisor will be assigned from within the Dept. of Anthropology. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Internship in Anthropology
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Fourth year; major or specialist in a program in Anthropology; 3.0 FCEs in Anthropology

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
To enrol in this course, please contact Josie Alaimo, the Undergraduate Administrator, at josie.alaimo@utoronto.ca

notes.name: Section Note
notes.content: December 2, 2020: Delivery method changed.

Student must fulfill responsibilities of the internship as well as complete a final research paper. notes.content:

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

To enrol in this course, please contact Josie Alaimo, the Undergraduate Administrator, at josie.alaimo@utoronto.ca

cmCourseInfo.description: Supervised independent research on a topic agreed on by the student and supervisor before enrolment in the course. Open in exceptional circumstances to advanced students with a strong background in Anthropology. Course Supervisor must be a member of the Anthropology faculty. Application for enrolment should be made to the Department in the preceding term. A maximum of one year of Independent Research courses is allowed per program. Not eligible for CR/NCR option.
cmCourseInfo.title: Independent Research
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: A minimum of 10 credits, permission of Supervisor and Undergraduate Coordinator.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
Application forms are available at the Anthropology Building located at 19 Russell Street, Room 258 or by contacting Josie Alaimo at josie.alaimo@utoronto.ca Completed forms must be returned by September 3, 2020. For more information, please contact josie.alaimo@utoronto.ca.
